item.title: Stress And Poverty May Explain High Rates Of Dementia In African-Americans
item.description: July 16, 2017 - New research finds that African-Americans who grow up in harsh environments and have many stressful experiences are much more likely to develop Alzheimer's or some other form of dementia.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 16, 2017 - New research finds that African-Americans who grow up in harsh environments and have many stressful experiences are much more likely to develop Alzheimer's or some other form of dementia. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/16/536935957/stress-and-poverty-may-explain-high-rates-of-dementia-in-african-americans

item.title: Shame, Guilt Pose Significant Hurdles For Those Recovering From Addiction
item.description: July 15, 2017 - For some, recovering from addiction is only half the battle. The other half is getting over the guilt, depression and shame associated with it. NPR's Michel Martin speaks with author Neil Steinberg.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 15, 2017 - For some, recovering from addiction is only half the battle. The other half is getting over the guilt, depression and shame associated with it. NPR's Michel Martin speaks with author Neil Steinberg. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/15/537451534/shame-guilt-pose-significant-hurdles-for-those-recovering-from-addiction

item.title: Amid Health Care Debate, Legislative Group Seeks To Foster Bipartisanship
item.description: July 15, 2017 - More and more lawmakers are seeking ways to build bipartisanship. NPR Host Michel Martin talks with co-chairs of the Problem Solvers Caucus, Congressmen Tom Reed and Josh Gottheimer, about health care.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 15, 2017 - More and more lawmakers are seeking ways to build bipartisanship. NPR Host Michel Martin talks with co-chairs of the Problem Solvers Caucus, Congressmen Tom Reed and Josh Gottheimer, about health care. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/15/537451509/amid-health-care-debate-legislative-group-seeks-to-foster-bipartisanship

item.title: A Terminal Illness Divides Parents And Doctors
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: PHOTOS: The Sidewalk Pill Peddlers Of Port-Au-Prince
item.description: July 15, 2017 - There aren't many pharmacies in Haiti. But there are vendors who walk the streets with towers of pills — including some that may be fake or past their expiration date.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 15, 2017 - There aren't many pharmacies in Haiti. But there are vendors who walk the streets with towers of pills — including some that may be fake or past their expiration date. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/15/537038311/photos-the-sidewalk-pill-peddlers-of-port-au-prince

item.title: Moms Need Social Support, And Not Just In The Baby Years
item.description: July 15, 2017 - Social support networks can help mothers of teenagers navigate through difficulties and maintain closeness with their children, researchers have found.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 15, 2017 - Social support networks can help mothers of teenagers navigate through difficulties and maintain closeness with their children, researchers have found. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/15/536657455/moms-need-social-support-and-not-just-in-the-baby-years

item.title: Doctor Shortage In Rural Arizona Sparks Another Crisis In 'Forgotten America'
item.description: July 14, 2017 - More than 70 rural U.S. hospitals have closed since 2010, and rural areas are likely to be short 45,000 doctors by 2020. It's one more example of the nation's division between haves and have-nots.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 14, 2017 - More than 70 rural U.S. hospitals have closed since 2010, and rural areas are likely to be short 45,000 doctors by 2020. It's one more example of the nation's division between haves and have-nots. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/14/535792864/doctor-shortage-in-rural-arizona-sparks-another-crisis-in-forgotten-america

item.title: What Moms Need To Breast-Feed: Chicken Soup, Grandma's Help, Facebook
item.description: July 14, 2017 - We invited readers to tell us how their culture helps moms become breast-feeding pros. The stories we received are so wonderful, we couldn't wait to share them. We even heard from a few dads!
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 14, 2017 - We invited readers to tell us how their culture helps moms become breast-feeding pros. The stories we received are so wonderful, we couldn't wait to share them. We even heard from a few dads! http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/07/14/535817998/what-moms-need-to-breast-feed-chicken-soup-grandmas-help-facebook

item.title: There's An Amazing New Drug For Multiple Sclerosis. Should I Try It?
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Who's In, Who's Left Out With The Latest Senate Health Care Bill
item.description: July 13, 2017 - Tax breaks for the wealthy would be trimmed, and people would get the option to buy bare-bones plans. But big cuts in Medicaid and changes to coverage for pre-existing conditions remain.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - Tax breaks for the wealthy would be trimmed, and people would get the option to buy bare-bones plans. But big cuts in Medicaid and changes to coverage for pre-existing conditions remain. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/13/537037194/whos-in-whos-left-out-with-the-latest-senate-health-care-bill

item.title: How Did Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever Pop Up In Spain?
item.description:
July 13, 2017 - The Ebola-like virus is found mainly in North Africa, the Middle East and Central Asia.

item.title: Sen. Tom Carper Explains How Democrats Could Work With GOP On Health Care
item.description: July 13, 2017 - NPR's Kelly McEvers talks with Democratic Sen. Tom Carper about how his party might work with Republicans to improve health care.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - NPR's Kelly McEvers talks with Democratic Sen. Tom Carper about how his party might work with Republicans to improve health care. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/13/537082064/sen-tom-carper-explains-how-democrats-could-work-with-gop-on-health-care

item.title: Senate Republicans Release New Version Of Health Care Bill
item.description: July 13, 2017 - Senate Republicans released a new version of their bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. It remains to be seen whether it can get enough support to pass.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - Senate Republicans released a new version of their bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. It remains to be seen whether it can get enough support to pass. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/13/537082057/senate-republicans-release-new-version-of-health-care-bill

item.title: Senate Health Care Bill Revisions Released In Attempt To Appease GOP Critics
item.description: July 13, 2017 - In need of more votes, Senate leaders have produced a new bill that offers billions more in opioid epidemic assistance but it keeps proposed cuts to Medicaid spending.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 13, 2017 - In need of more votes, Senate leaders have produced a new bill that offers billions more in opioid epidemic assistance but it keeps proposed cuts to Medicaid spending. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/13/537040114/senate-gop-releases-revised-affordable-care-act-repeal-and-replace-plan
